Bottle from Mam and Dads Holiday, Netherlands. Hazy straw coloured with a thick white head of foam. It has a sweet toffee, citrus and lemon flavour with peppery hop notes and a sweet fruity finish. Good but a bit too high ABV for the flavour.

Quand on lit la remarque commerciale sur ratebeer, il y a de quoi attraper un fou-rire...
En effet, on y parle de longues discussions sur le style de cette bière, alors que précisément celui-ci ne pose strictement aucun problème !! A linverse, la majorité du temps, le classement serait discutable, et on classe sans aucune concertation.. Ici donc on discute beaucoup avant de classer alors que le classement est évident, il y a de quoi se rouler par terre !!!
En effet, une bière en fermentation basse est une lager, et comme son niveau abv est élevé (8,7 %),
il sagit donc bien sûr dune "strong pale lager", encore appelée imperial pils ..
Aucun problème, et classement évident.
Signalons quand même leffort du brasseur pour faire du dry hopping sur cette bière et pour la refermenter en bouteille, ce qui est rare pour une lager, mais ce qui nentraîne aucun changement pour son classement 
Dry hopping donc en tettnanger et bramling cross.
Mon exemplaire était à 8 mois avant sa date.
Couleur doré pâle, avec un léger voile presque comme une blanche.
Bulles fines, partout, très vives.
Mousse blanche épaisse, avec structure plus ferme en haut, stable à 10 mm.
Arômes de malt pils, grillé, citron, pointe de mangue, houblon vif.
1ère bouche très souple à lentame malt/citron/feuilles dacanthe.
Arrière-bouche sur malt pils et coriandre.
2ème au joli ensemble bien malté avec citron et épices.
Arrière-bouche longue, prégnante, jolie.
3ème au très beau maltage.
Arrière-bouche équilibrée.
Longueur qui prolonge les mêmes impressions, sans pourtant les sublimer.
Jambes fines, longues, un peu collantes en haut.
Levure fine, un peu épicée, très belle ligne.
Alcool très correct, il soutient manifestement la longueur.
Finale à la belle amertume, mais un peu pâteuse ..
CONCLUSION : belle impériale pils, à qui il ne manque quun peu plus dharmonie et une longueur plus enthousiaste .. Pas le Nobel, mais un prix de consolation ...

Nice murky blonde pour. Sweet tones of honey, but also a lot of fresh, citrus tones

The flavor found similar.. touches of honey and fruits at the core, but lots of wet cardboard and other paper-like notes throughout.. slick finish with tacky, unappealing malts and a touch of peppery spice. Medium-bodied and slick on the palate with almost no carbonation.. just not good.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2016

Aroma:

Slight/medium aroma of malts, Belgian yeast, honey, caramel, fruit, straw and hops.

Appearance:

Turbid/opaque yellow/golden beer with medium yeast and with a slight/medium white/off-white head.

Taste/Palate:

Starts medium sweet with malts, Belgian yeast, honey, caramel and fruit; ends slightly bitter and dry with straw and hops.

Overall:

This beer is rather intense, complex and balanced. I can imagine the debate about the style of this beer, feels like a Belgian Ale/Imperial Pilsener mix. It manages to do this without a problem. The aroma could have been stronger, the appearance is great and unfiltered, the flavour is decent all-over and the palate is great.
Decent stuff. Did they re-label recently? Finds a balance between mostly herbal bitterness and a slight sweet aftertaste. Nothing out of the ordinary but decent fare.

Interesting mix of Belgian sweetness with a light body & clean body. Nice & amazing that a mainstream Imperial Pils is this good. Man De Proef The sweetness does get a touch too much in the end as does the milky nature.

Bottle - Hazy golden colour, persistent white head. Bready aromas, hay, spicy nose. Taste is sweet malt, cereals, grassy hops, some orange peel. Medium body and carbonation, smooth texture but a bit offensive alcohol. Good.

Grassy perfumy nose witn some peach. Dryish with fairlym light body and clean, rounded mouthfeel.

Tastes like malt, slightly bitter hops, light caramel, fruity and slightly sweet.
Nice long bitter aftertaste, refreshing.

The finish is long and light bitter and very refreshing. Very nice pilsner, the very first imperal pils which I really like.

Does not present its strength in either the aroma, feel or taste. Lightly sweet with a hint of rose petals. Middle is laced with herbal hops, with notes of wintergreen and white pepper that carry into the finish and linger. Smooth and mildly prickly in feel. A hopped up maibock of sorts. BOTTLE 33 CL from Douberd.

Look: almost clear golden, very creamy white head.
Aroma: beautiful German hops, flowery and lemony, a bit of sweetness and some glue.
Taste: a nice strong body, some sweetness and quite hoppy.

Smell is wood and resin, with subtle grainy caramel sweetness, touch of leather. Typical German bitterness.
Dry bitter beer, reminds me of a British ale, but dominated by typical German feel. Touch of caramel, alcohol. Orange peel finish.
Nice. Interesting choice of hops, very original.

Slightly hazy body, deep golden in colour, with a big white head on top, thick and with great retention. Medium lacing left on the glass.
Aroma of malts, heavy on the straw, light alcohol, some grains. 
Taste also of malts, sugars, light grains especially on the finish, very notable alcohol, giving it some medicinal notes, straw but also traces of hops. 
Medium body, carbonation on good levels.

2014: citrus, alcohol, golden, cloudy, very bitter, lively, bitter, A tasty hoppy dutch beer. A good pick for any beer drinker who?s into beers on the bitter end.

Finishes with a good amount of bitterness that almost balances out the sweetness, and a nice warm alcohol flavor. Mild but fizzy carbonation with a medium-full body and a fairly sticky texture. Overall, a decent hoppy ale, which isnt so easy to find in the Netherlands. Has both nice hop aroma and flavor with enough malt to balance the bitterness. This used to be one of my favorites brewed in NL, but the original company went out of business and the new version isnt quite as good.

Aroma floral, lagerish in the nose, flavor is fruits, malt, candy sweets, syrup, honey, cereal, vanilla, slight citrus and hops. Alcohol is quite well hidden. Taste medium to heavy sweetness, lightly bitter, hint of citric sourness. Medium body, sticky texture, soft carbonation, sweet lagerish finish with some IPAish and spring beer notes. Refreshing, easy to drink, very interesting, but a bit too sweet for me.

33cl bottle at home. Pale golden with a medium white soapy head. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Medium sweet- and bitterness. Citrus, herbs, tangerine and yeast. A more then decent brew.

White with no lacing and diminishes to a small ring. Color is muddy medium amber/tan. Flavor starts moderately to heavily sweet and slightly acidic, then finishes moderately sweet and slightly bitter. Palate is medium, oily with a soft carbonation and a lightly astringent and chewy finish. A drinkable beer but this Strong Pale Lager is a little too homebrew-esque for me.

Draft sample. Poured clear golden color with medium frothy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Medium complex balanced aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. My expectations where met twice.

Would probably be much better fresh.

I had this at Global Brew. Pours clear gold with a white head. Taste lightly sweet, light fruit. I thought this was so so. I could drink this again.

fresh sweet malty nose, bread, floral, herbs, dough, grass, kinda light hazy golden, small frothy white head, disappears quickly though not completely, light lacing, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy mouthfeel, smooth dry bitter finish, a bit spicy and some alcohol sharpness, all together well-balanced.

Its like a more full bodied and fresh tasting white beer, but better :)

Hazy golden yellow with white foam head. Aroma is hard to detect. Taste is bittersweet, hops prevael. Aftertaste is long lasting bitter beer. (Velp 201301)

Barely no aroma on this one but I know its usually nice and hoppy. A bit sour and yeasty though. Slightly darker than the bier/blonde. Sweet in taste but no alcohol even if its 8,7%. Malty with some bitterness. Usually this one is a bit better than bier but this one has lost some hops. Very nice body. Sort of belgian in style, but I think its better. Brouwerij tIj has some beer that is similar and also excellent. Christoffel is a quality brewery without so much experimental stuff. Solid great beer but without freakiness. Jopen, emelisse and de molen are of a more freaky nature, Ij somewhere in between. Theyre all good though. Will certainly enjoy again.

MF: ok carbon, medium body, creamy texture. Taste: grains, hay, pretty bitter, herbal liquor, alcohol. Aftertaste: pretty grassy, little fruity, yeast, bitter dry ending.
Corked 33 cl bottle @ home. Pours cloudy golden with a white head that leaves a little lacing. Aroma is sweet malt, grains, and floral hops. Flavour is much like the aroma.

Dirty cloudy gold with specks of sediment, big bubbly head and streaks of lace.  The first thing I notice is the alcohol - it arrives early, and provides warmth far beyond the finish.  The taste begins with sweet malt that is given a hard push by floral bitters.  Both sides are so persistent that neither can gain a strong enough foothold to dismiss the other.  Most of the flavor shows up in the back of the mouth with a fullness that suggests sipping may be the only way to enjoy this.  I like it, but one is enough.

Poured from a bottle (at home Feb 12) into a tulip glass to a murky dark yellow/amber colour with a good finger of frothy white head.

All round dryed hop aroma, very fresh with a little mint in the nose and grass/straw lurking in the background. If you sniff hard with your nose to the beer you really get an alcohol whiff!

Taste wise - zesty citrus hoppy taste with relatively strong alcohol flavour in the aftertaste also slightly peppery in the aftertaste!

Quite a lot of carbonation going on with a medium body to this beer in terms of mouthfeel. Head subsided to a small ocean of a covering whilst drinking and a little lacing around the edge of the glass.

Overall an OK beer, but not one Id revisit given the choice over others.

The alcohol flavour is too pronounced for me and not balanced enough.

Sweet with hay, light honey and pears; gentle lemon, a little grapefruit and herbs. Long bitter herbal end. Alcohol is remarkably well-hidden for a strong lager. I liked it a lot given what it is, but its not as good as the Blond.

On tap at Pinocchios.  Very intriguing beer.  Straw colored, opaque.  Fruity esters in the nose.  Sweet grainy pils flavors in the malt base.  Some light banana and pineapple fruitiness.  Some grassy/hay hop finish.  Perfectly carbonated.  Very well done.

Absolutely delicous, hoppy pilsner. It has not been filtered or anything so you can see some hazyness which is of course nice if you really like beer. Very hoppy in a nice way. Strong beer, beautiful head and colour. One of the best beers overall!
Sweet. Dry finish. Raspberry and peach mostly. Slightly bitter in the finish. Apart from being a little too sweet this is well made. Bottle from Van Erp in Groningen.

Unclear dark yellow with and off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, fruity, alcohol.  and moderate hoppy - herbal and earthy. Flavor is medium sweet and rather bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. 200112

Pale, a great white head, fresh hop aroma, flowers, a little bit "minty".
Medium body, full of hops, fruity, melon, citrus, little bit "minty", bitter and a long aftertaste. Balance and soft.  A great beer, maybe the best beer in the Netherlands.
Pours cloudy yellow with a white head. Aroma is light malt and grass. Flavour is malt, grass, pine, flower and fruity notes.

Bijna perfect bier. Afgelopen zaterdag een leuke presentatie gehad van Bart van de Christoffel-brouwerij uit Roermond. Vijf verschillende bieren met de naam Christoffel en één van Martens met de naam Kristoffel. De Christoffel Nobel vond ik met vlag en wimpel boven de andere uit steken. 330ml swing top bottle, cloudy honey gold hue, with a bubbly white head, with a floral zesty, lime, lemon peel hop nose, with some faint lemongrass, minty leafy spiciness notes, within a light honeyed pale, pilsener malt aroma follows through on amedium-bodied palate with a nice yeasty, fruity, citrusy, flowery lemon, grapefruit peel, leafy, grassy hop character with some herbal, flower petal, lemongrass, subtle cardamom spicy flavors, with a faint honeyish pale, pilsener malt undertone, leading towards a yeasty, zesty fruitiness, leafy, grassy, lemon, lime rind hop bitterness finish.

a Beer to be proud of...! Nobel is a good drinkeble beer with an unique taste of trou ingerdients. The normal Chrsitofeel is fine, but the Nobel is even better. Its the best dutch special beer on the market.

Cloudy brownish yellow, with a decent sized whitehead. Smells sweet, cakey and yeasty. Flavor is sweet and yeasty, as well. Every single bit of its 8.7% is on display, too. Crisp, grassy finish. Meh. Cool bottle, though...

33cl bought in Bodegraven, Holland.
BB end 2013.
Dorée, col blanc crémeux.
Arôme assez neutre, houblon et citronné. En bouche, palais est sec avec une note levure et épice. Malt pale, cara avec une fine amertume. Notre grains; froment avec en retrait ajout de caramel et de grillé. Note fruitée tropical allant vers la mangue.

Nice white head. Cloudy golden. Floral and citrus aroma. Slight sweetness (honeylike) with a bitter wash. Light to medium body with thin texture and nice average carbonation. Nice medium long finish (can match a well aged cheese). Not bad for a strong pilsner - but not special either.

Opaque, dull orange with fine, tight carbonation. Head was solid and lasting, a dense, compact pad just off-white that laced well. Spruce and lavender, canteloupe and bitter, underripe honeydew on the nose with edges of fairy floss and orange sherbet, a little yeast and tickling spice. In high gear on the palate. Pronounced nettles, weeds and vine clippings amongst some supple, sweet and bitter citrus fruit. Good, firm mouthfeel, spritzy in the front smoothing out as it heads back. Swallow is weedy and tangy, nice depth of bitter fruit comes through and lingers well with a touch of warming alcohol. Almost candyish as it goes, but not overly sweet, the fruit nicely balanced, the malt profile all but absent. Struggle to call this a ramped up Pilsner but it is a refreshing number. Good stuff! (33cL, BBE 12/12, Mane Liquor, Belmont)
Its good.  Not as nobel as the double hopped blond but still very decent.  Less of a strong aroma.

Bottle at RBESG 09 Grand Tasting in  Sheffield. Hazy gold color, with a lasting head. Smella and tastes liek a lager on steroids, but in a good way. Strong herbal character as well and noticeable hop presence.

Think I mightve gotten a bum one here. I let this warm a bit out of the fridge. Poured with a decent foamy, frothy off white head that was short lived, some yeast sediment, and no lace. Color is a cloudy amber brown. Aroma is yeast, raisins, other fruit, malt. Flavor is like now but big raisin sweetness countering the tartness and yeast bitterness. No hop noticable anywhere. Body was full and thick with ok carbonation. Finish is like flavor and longish. Not at all like a pils. Would like to try a good one.

33 cl. swing top bottle. Pours a fluffy, lasting white head, with attractive lacing, over a hazy yellow gold (SRM 4) body...nose is cereal, toast, light sugar....taste is cereal, light pear, apple, finishing with a sweet alcohol tone with lingering hop bitterness....mouth feel light, alcohol present, carbonation low. The beer meets this rather nebulous style, however, it has a lighter mouth feel than many, and the alcohol burn is too obvious. Finally, in fairness, the style (Strong Pale Lager) is not a favorite of mine. BJCP 7/3/12/4/6
Van de tap in buitenlust, oirschot. Gele heldere kleur, stinkt naar de gierton. Smaakt daarentegen zoet en een beetje bitter.
swingtop bottle from the LCBO. Pours hazy yellow with a white head. Hoppy and malty aroma. bitter and dry. Im not a fan of highly-hopped beers but this was exceptional.

0.33l bottle from CrackedKettle web shop. This is a light cloudy pale orange beer with a big and lasting light creamy and fluffy white head. The aroma is filled with cactus, lots of citrus-fruity tones, bubblegum and malts with notes of sugar and lots of hops. Really nice aroma. Average carbonation, medium-bodied with a light oily mouthfeel. Flavors are also kinda mild-fruity without going to fruity. Lots of citrus here and a good amount of malts. Ends with a distinct alcohol-touch, a dry finish and a lasting warming aftertaste. Really nice stuff!

33 cl swingtop. Clear, brassy with a small, lasting creamy foam. Aroma is sweet caramel, beeswax, light orange, leaf and resin. Taste is the same unique mix  with some honey toasted grain. The finish becomes increasingly drier with more earthy leaf, citrus zest and resin showing up to sweep away the big malt front. Medium body is well-balanced by the dry finish, smoothly carbonated and has some slight alcohol warmth.
Very hazy pale yellow colour with a decent white head. Smells weird but fresh. Tastes very refreshing, fruity and herbs. Good mouthfeel.

(blind-sampled at Election Day Pale Lager Challenge) Pours a cloudy golden with little, white head that laces the glass. The aroma is vegetal with some sour notes. Oily  texture, full bodied, medium carbonation and a long, astringent finish. The taste is moderately bitter. Girlfriend says: "I dont like the alcohol taste in it."

Thanks to yourefragile for picking this up somewhere in Maryland for me. Served in a Mikasa tulip.

Popping the top yields a bit of a hiss, after I finally got the rubber up, as it was quite stuck on the lip of the bottle. Pour initially yields a few bubbles and no real head. Bit of a galaxy swirl on top of the brew as well as a thin collar. Dark peach body is translucent.

Nose brings forward a lot of pilsener malt plus a bit of herbal and floral hops. Theres a slight fruitiness in the nose that becomes more apparent in the flavor. Fairly hoppy with a bit of bitterness, though the main character is a strong pilsner-malt sweetness. To the beers credit, theres no noticeable alcohol. However, the sweetness and fruits dont really fit. Quite bready and a bit chewy.

Body is medium without noticeable levels of alcohol. Light carbonation. Full and chewy; not at all crisp. Some light bitterness in the finish, though the hoppy character is mostly in the nose, as a result of the dry hopping, Im sure.

Decent enough, but not something Id ever want to drink again.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Hazy yellow pour with a slightly off white, fluffy head. Huge grass notes on the nose. Grass, earth and light fruits make up the aroma. A caramel fruit and grass follow through in the taste. Solid
Pours hazy gold into a snifter. White head with good retention recedes leaving spot lacing. Sweet citrus aromas. Dry, sweet caramel upfront and lasting hot citrus finish.

(Bottled) Hazy yellow-golden with a medium, lacy and lasting head. Crisp, lemony-herby-flowery, dry-hopped nose. Flavor is very aromatic-hoppy, ultra-clean, herby and strongly lemony, with a pleasantly malty, but not too heavy backbone. Just the right amount of bitterness all the way through. Medium body, slightly fizzy but balanced CO2, refreshing, hides the ABV completely. Very balanced, clean and enjoyable - definitely one of the best strong lagers Ive had. 4645

Bottle. Poured out being hazy, yellow with a fluffy white head. Really interesting how this beer looks. Aroma has malts and some yeast. Really fresh and inviting. Flavour is a bit sweet, with bitter aftertaste. Goes down well. Never thought I could drink a pilsner with that much alcohol and liking it. But I did. Then I found out it was an Imperial Pilsner. Bottled. Poured slightly hazy and yellow with a large foamy, off-white head head. Fair lacings. Nose of nuts and grassy hops. Sweet flavour with grass, fruit and caramel notes. Medium bodied, creamy texture and an average carbonation. Slightly bitter finish. An OK brew.
Bottle @ Cafe Buitenlust, Oirschot. Hazy yellow color, small head. Smell light fruits. Taste hops and medium bitter. Medium carbo and body.
Bottle at Huppel.  Very cloudy yellow pour with medium white head.  Aroma is hoppy and slightly nutty with some spice.  Flavour is bitter hops with citrus, malt and an alcohol warmth in the finish

Bottle. Large creamy almost beige looking head that mostly lasted. Fair display of lacework. Cloudy orange color. Aroma of fruit, light toasted malt, hint of herbs and grass. Medium bodied with an average carbonation and light dry texture. Light bitter and sweet flavor in balance. Light dry and bitter finish.

Looks like wheat beer. Orange yellow, hazy and has white foamy head. Smells a little citrus. Taste is bitter, ale type. Theres a lot of hops. I also find yeast aromas, leather & basement. Texture is oily and carbonation is lively. Finish is long. Perhaps a bit too bitter to me, while being too sweet at the same time.
(Bottle 16/07-2011) Large lasting white head, unclear yellow/orange color, smooth taste. Dont think it was fresh, since dry hop seem to have faded (BB date: A 12 2011).

In short: A bready, somewhat sweet, a bit boozy and moderately hoppy (grassy/herbal/spicy) strong blonde lager.  Just ok.
How: Bottle 330ml, flip-top.  Consumed fresh the day after purchase, new batch received at LCBO spring 2011
The look: Cloudy blonde body topped by a medium white head with low retention leaving good lacings on the glass
In long: Nose is canned pineapples, herbal hops.  Taste is bready cereals, spiciness certainly coming from the hops, dough, salt, white sugar, pears, canned pineapples, some dry grass, a bit of booze.  This beer had disappeared from the LCBO for a good six months, and then it reappeared in large quantities, so I assumed it was a fresh batch.  But the bottle I drank lacked crispness and there was some slightly overripe fruits flavors.  Poor transport condition or a not-so-fresh batch put on the shelves?  A far cry from their excellent Christoffel Blond which is one of the best bottled pilsner on the planet.  Basically I was expecting a lot more so this beer was a disappointment to me.  I should have suspected I would be disappointed when I bought the beer and the cashier at LCBO didnt tell me have a nice day.  She knew.

Aroma is very sweet doppelbock-esque caramel, and spicy, woody hops.  Taste is surprisingly clean and dry for the cloyingly sweet smell with notes of cereal, spruce, pine, and bread. Hazy light yellow colour with thick,medium head with some lacing. Aromasstrong hoppy aroma, plums and some spice and alcohol is sensable on the nose. Taste is very hoppy pilsener strong and yet refreshing. Medim body and oily texture with medium carbonation.

Cloudy and frothy in the glass. slight lace, nice straw yellow and cream colour. spiced aromas, bannana, nutmeg, nutty and some hay and pine cones. aroma is bitter, hoppy, fuller bodied. im liking this brew.
Sampler at CBF 2011-05-27. Murky yellow with a creamy, white film. Spicy aroma with notes of banana and malts. Rich malty flavor, hops and alcohol present. Full bodied with a dough like texture.

Bottle. Hazy golden yellow colour, medium-sized creamy white head. Grassy-hoppy, a little peppery malty aroma with a whiff of citrus fruits. The flavour is malty, a little dry, with citrus fruits, hops, alcohol and a warm finish. Medium-bodied, moderately carbonated.

A prominent  malty sweetness is quickly curbed by a lively resinous and bitter hop character; finishes with nice pine and citrus aromatics and just the faintest hint of booze.  Fairly full bodied, beyond what I was expecting for sure, almost sticky and syrupy on the palate.  Certainly unique, and very drinkable...glad I stumbled upon this one.

Slightly hazy straw gold colour, fluffy white head. Aroma of malt, ripe fruits, cloves, pine and tangerine peel. Nicely hoppy. Bit sweet malts flavour, deep hops keynote. Ripe fruits, cloves, grass, woodruff, some lime. Lingering hops in the finish.

May 6, 2011; 330mL Swingtop bottle, cellared, BBD: Oct/12; served in footed pilsner.

same bottle as pictured. poured hazy yellow with good head, good head retention. faint aroma of hops. smooth mouth feel, pretty easy drinking. nice hop flavours with lemon and some faint malts. overall very good.

Pale straw, firm white head, slightly cloudy. Hoppy, fruity, estery nose, hints of yeast, malt, citrus. Medium body, off-dry, medium bitter. Hoppy, fruity, citrusy taste, quite evident alcohol, slightly earthy, bitter, tart finish. (2011-02-09)

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic.

Kind of hilarious, actually.  These just arrived in the area (no bottle date, though), but theyre quite oxidized already.  Lets follow the trail of laughs.  First, the bottle itself...see the picture on this page?  The neck label is the same, but the imports Ive seen dont have the body label.  Instead, theyre just narrow white labels (one on the front and one on back) that are about the same size as ordinary stick-on envelope address labels, complete with plain black low-resolution jagged fonts that look like they were made with a Commodore 64 (with which I used to make labels just like these when I was a teenager! ah, memories!).  Fabulously awful.  Ok, so now lets pour the beer.  Whoa, check it out!  Theres almost as much sludge in here as that godawful first batch (or was it the second, I cant remember now) of bottled Dark Lord.  So much muck, so little time...lets take a whiff.  Oooooh, baby!  Oxidation and dirt are jumping out of the glass, stand back and make room!  Whee, theres even some stinky feet in there too.  And yep, that stale papery aftertaste is there, so obviously not ALL of the oxidation has leaped from the glass!  Now, granted, there are some apricotty hops in the nose too, which as it breathes eventually become dominant.  This was more of an amusing experience than a truly wretched one, so Im glad to have had it.  90% of it went down the drain, but the memory will live for a long time to come.  Hard to imagine this is what the brewer intended, but until next time, I will assume the worst...

text: I do like this Dutch brewer, so seeing another one of their flip-top bottles at the LCBO made me happy. Beautiful big fluffy white head that has lots of retention and artsy lacing. The hop is also present all the way through the tasting, but not bitter (because of the dry-hopping). Alcohol is very well-hidden and hints of grain malt and pear are found as well. Pretty easy drinkability and quite a nice different beer.

Bottle and served in my Duvel snifter, #3 of my Strong Lager tasting: Pours a deep golden hue with a lasting frothy white head and very nice lacework upon the glassware. The aroma has notes of heavy Saaz hops and some PNW hops too (citric and a tad resiny), pale biscuity and wheat grains, slight pear and tangerine esters, minerally and dusty yeast, along with a what can only be described as a rye bread snap. The taste starts with a moderately sharp herbal bitterness followed by mostly clean grain and just a hint of butterscotch. There is a light handed but constant tropical and domestic fruity component here before a shockingly sharp peppery and caraway seed spicy finish. The mouth feel is a tad too aggressive but unlike many of these "Imperialized" or over hopped lagers, this actually attempts to hide the alcohol and does not provide those off aromas and flavors often found in these over the top attempts. I can understand why this is among the higher rated of this new bastardized genre, leave it to a good European "craft" brewery to show how you can do these "imperialized" lagers and still make it approachable and somewhat enjoyable.  Good call by the admins on the placement of the beer within styles.

Little swingtop bottle from the LCBO. 8.7%. Hazy yellowish amber pour with a lasting white head, thick and frothy. Lots of aromas here, citrusy hoppiness present as well as some caramel, and a spiciness. Taste is bold citrusy hops, tempered with a sweet, bready consistency that disguises the alcohol content. Finish is quite dry, lingering pleasant spicy burn.

Tap at Rattle n Hum. Pours hazy amber with a faint, filmy white head. Sharp malt aroma with floral notes and some citrus hops. Flavor is quite sweet with more citrus and florals. Medium bodied with average carbonation and some warmth. Finishes sweet with malts and fruit. Very nice.

Absolutely massive permanent thick very light tan cap that has the consistency of shaving cream. Dull hazy dark apricot colour. Stunning presentation in this Corsendonk glass. Aromas of passion fruit, hints of English IPAs, caramel and bread, notable English spice, lemons as well. Very tasty! I wish I had more. Caramel, very tangy citrus hops, spice burn is good. Lots of tasty hops was a bit of a surprise, light herbal quality.. my love for this beer only faded out on the last sips. Almost medium bodied, long hop hit. Very enjoyable colder, less less enjoyable when warmer.

On tap at the Doerak in Delft as a guest beer.
Very cloudy blond.  Decent head.  A very nice beer.  Very drinkable!  Worth trying
33cl, new Dutch brew Anno 2008, from Melgers Haarlem, complex brew, balanced, cloudy, rocky head, good yet original brew!, better than the Speciale Editie

Bottle at the Bookstore.  Pours a hazy golden orange with a creamy off white head.  Aroma of noble hops, orange, sweet malt and apples.  Flavor of dry malt with sweet candy notes, noble spicy hops and citrus notes.

.33 swingtop from Rare Beers in Budapest. This is a nice one! Pours hazy yeast-cloudy golden yellow. Foamy head dissipates to a crescent around the edge of the glass. Nose is strong spiced and citrusy hops on top of belgian-like yeast. Cool, sweet orange and clove/christmas spices. First sip is bright and fruity with medium carbonation, warms with alcohol and hop citrus. Finishes smooth with a back end of round hoppiness after the fruity body. Really terrific and a great surprise.

Bottle from Bier Konig in Amsterdam. Wonderful fresh hop aroma--noble, with citrus, pine. Dark yellow, a dull pastel, with a high, fine head. Lovely pine hop flavor, citrus, grass. Fresh but not green or medicinal. Nice pils malt, light sweetness, some honey and fruit--slight bt of tropical fruit. Peppery, tangy finish. Wonderful hoppiness, moderate bitterness. Wow! Great.

33 cl bottle, pours golden with a huge white head, excellent retention and lots of lacings, aroma of grain, malt and a bit of spice, taste is grain, malt and spice, slightly bitter, decent finish, solid beer.

A hazy golden amber pils  with a thick onctuous off white head. Aroma of intense herbaceous hops, almost pinhey. but also rather German. In mouth, a crisp malt with sharp German-Czech hops, herbal and intense, lingering in mouth. Rich and sharp. LCBO offering-Spring 2010.

Pours a hazy golden color with a medium, creamy white head. Nice aroma of hops, citrus and malt. Flavor of hops, malt and citrus, theres also some alcohol warmth. The body is light with a creamy texture and lively carbonation.

Ködös arany színe van, tömött és tejszín jellegü habja hosszan marad  meg és a buborékok élénken pezsegnek a pohár szélén.
Illata virágos, fűszeres.
Íze malátás, textúrája kellemes, sima. 
Aromája virágos, fűszeres és enyhén citrusos egyveleg.
Befejezése fűszeres, alkoholosan melengető és száraz, mely után egy gyantás utóíz marad meg.
Az alkohol, kerek egészt alkotva, nem lóg ki a sörből, mely összességében igen jó benyomást tett rám.
Hazy gold pour, frothy white head. Bready malt, slightly earthy, grapefruit, bitter citrusy hops, grass, and some tropical fruit.  Nice.

Bouteille 330ml, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur dorée-jaune et voilée. Nez de levures fruitées (agrumes), de houblon herbeux (herbes fraîches), légèrement floral et aux petites notes citriques, moyen de grains de céréales, léger de pain avec des traces dalcool. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture léger-moyen crémeuse. Goût de levures fruitées (agrumes) accompagné dun moyenne amertume de houblon floral et légèrement citrique (pamplemousse) et de traces dépices (poivre) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût de grains de malt pâle sucrés, de céréales, léger de pain avec des petites traces de biscuits puis en finale lamertume de houblon revient en étant plus herbeuses (herbes fraîches, notes de foin) et accompagné de notes dalcool. Post-goût moyen et asséchant,  moyennement amer de houblon herbeux et légèrement citrique avec un léger goût de levures fruitées (zest dagrumes) et des traces dalcool.

330 ml swingtop bottle, from Voldby Købmandsgård, Denmark. Dry hopped, unfiltered, unpasteurised, bottom fermented, classic open fermentation. ABV is 8.7%. Very pale yellow hazy beer, huge white head. Strong aroma of floral and herbal European hops, notes of grass and alcohol too. The flavour is sweet, hoppy and quite alcoholic. Strong and sweet pale lagers rarely "go home" with me, and this one is no exception, even though it is much better than its more industrial counterparts.

330ml Bottle:  Aroma of yeast, malt, and grain.  Poured a muddy, brown/flaxen/gold color with a small, off-white/tan head that disappeared except for around the edges.  Cloudy.  Not sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Flavor is medium sweet and a tad bitter.  Tastes of yeast, malt, slight hops, slight honey, and some grain.  Medium body.  Slick, then lightly dry texture.  Soft carbonation.  Yeast, malt, and slight honey finish is lightly dry.  8.7%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy pale orange with a soft merangue of a head. Beautiful aroma of fresh tangerines, citrus oil, and something floral (lavender?..no...). Light palate despite the ABV, creamy mouthfeel. Very hoppy flavour profile, lots of citrus rind and tropical fruit, with a bitter dry finish.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text:
UPDATED: MAY 3, 2011 Bottle.Pours cloudy yellow/white with a white head.Aroma of herbal,skunky  hops and sweet malt.Flavour is bitter herbal,floral,green hops and sweet malt.Medium body,medium carbonation. Very nice and hoppy beer.
7-4-8-4-15


Bottle on the train to Antwerpen , courtesy of Beer 2000.
Pours clear golden with a big white head.Aroma of herbal hops,, some fruitiness, yeast and green apples.Flavor is sweet and bitter with some  herbal and grassy notes.Sharp alcohol. Medium body ,average carbonation.
6-4-6-4-13

330 ml. From LCBO. Pours yellow. Rather murky. Small whitehead, but impressive lace. Slight "cactus" aroma, somewhat skunky as well. Has some traces of bread, probably due to yeast. Palate is rather citrusy as well : that beer is certainly hoppy, but theres something wrong here. Too much of an alcoholic taste. Disappointed, considering ratings, but I cant exactly give a reason why. Might give it another chance someday. 

EDIT : Got it! Really, really strong grapefruit taste. I hate grapefruit.

Le liquide est jaune pâle et voilée.  On peut observer de fines bulles et une bonne effervescence.  En guise de tête, une mousse blanche épaisse qui finit par laisser de petites traces sur le verre.  Au nez, la présence dherbes fraîches est soutenue par un malt qui dégage un bon arôme de pâte à biscuit.  En arrière-plan, fleur de miel et fruit.  Présence dune touche poivrée, peut-être attribuable au degré élevée de lalcool.  En bouche, le goût de la levure, du malt doux et des houblons francs donnent une finale sèche et légèrement imprégnée dalcool.  La sensation du liquide sur la langue est douce et crémeuse.  Arrière-goût amer durable pour cette bière qui possède une structure moyennement dense.

33 cl bottle, Toronto, ON, Canada. Hazy light apricot, grapefruit and coriander aroma. Very bright taste, honey sweetness in the background with a white pepper and citrus predominating. Warming alcohol finish that balances with sweetness.
Bottle.Hazy golden colour with large white head.Aroma of cactus and lime bitter with fruity dry mouthfeels and strong hoppy flavor with hint of mint abd wheat.

330 swingtop. Man, this one is fun. Pours a murky, butterscotch-looking light golden amber with a dense and creamy white head. Big sweet nose, a little boozy, floral hops, with some toffee and caramel in there as well. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Caramel, toffee, and a bit of ginger on the mid-palate, with bright peppery hops carrying along into a spicily hopped finish. Very quenching and even refreshing for being as heavy and boozy as it is. If this had been made with ale yeast, it would probably be a heavy sipper at best. As it is, its awfully easy to drink for being nearly 9.

bottle. Poured cloudy yellow with yeast sediment  and a film of a head. An orangey hop aroma. Full mouthfeel with a dry palate. Flavour is hoppy, grapfruity, and a touch nutty. A sticky, spicy bitter finish.

Bottle from the LCBO- Slightly hazed golden pour, has a huge bleached white froth, with good lace. Nose if fresh floral hops with anise, grass, biscuit, white plum. Tastes quite hoppy. Lots of anise, floral hops, rose petal, marked bitterness with sweet bready malts. Creamy and distinct hoppy bitterness at the end. An interesting combination. very good.

My Bottom Line:
Blooming herbal hops and bready, doughy yeast combine, while lightly citrusy currents and ample pilsener malts create complexity.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam skirts the cloudy golden.
-The amped-up, fresh noble hop nose was reminiscent of some Franconian Kellerbiers.
-The pils malts produce slightly sulphuric notes.
-The relaxed effervescence makes for a comfy mouthfeel.
-With a flavor profile like this, Id prefer something like 5% abv. But this is still very good for what it is and Id have it anytime I get a chance to see it. 

Bottle; merci David!

On tap at Copenhagen Beer Festival 2010
Rich, fruity beer, refreshing. The hops kick in - with more aroam than dryness - in the tail. Saison-like, there is both fruit and funkiness in this.

Spectacular appearance as a white tower gathers over the pale, completely veiled golden liquid. Grainy, cerealic nose where the high  alcohol content remains relatively subtle. Certainly more malty than the blonde, it does have a strong white bread, almost doughy character. Chive-like, herbal, spicy hops appear less floral than in the blonde.  Undoudtedly, more residual sugars inhabit this medium-full bodied fella, whose medium-bubbled carbonation nonetheless remain active enough to cleanse the palate between sips. Alcohol more than sneaks up as the finish deploys, confusing slightly the green, highly herbal, almost onion-like hops. All throughout, not so soft malts keep insisting upon their bread concentrate notions. Many good elements here, the cleanliness is all here, the texture and looks are beyond reproach and the higher gravity does not come with any agressivity. While the more drinkable (less residual sugars and heat) blonde is far more enjoyable, this remains an excellent drink, it just isnt very clear what purpose a strong blonde lager serves as the flavour concentration inevitably removes from the ingredients purity and freshness impression.

Usually Iam not found of lagers and low fermented beers. But this ones terrific. Burnt caramel and hops on the nose. What a nice mixture and well balanced brew. The palate is floral due to hops, and the sweetness of the caramel malt gives a very delicate smoothness.
Hazy gold with average off-white head. Aroma is of fruit, malt and grain.Taste is of apple, hops, and lemon.

Bottle pours a murky orange yellow with a well presented head, lacing the glass and lasting throughout . Very nice floral aromas of the dry hopped goldings and complex flavours due to the suspended yeast in the bottle. Also some dry hop particles were found in the bottle, but of no consequence to the overall experience. A touch bitter & sour on the finish, probably due to the interaction with the suspended yeast, however definitely an interesting lager beer for once.

0,33 l bottle from Csakajosor.hu
Poured golden yellow with a tall white lacing foam. Flowers, citrus, hops, yeast in the sour aroma. Medium dense body with malty and hoppy taste. Refreshing, very enjoyable lager.

Bottle. Slight hazy golden yellow pour, medium creamy off white head.
Aroma is citrus and floral hops with some fruit.
Flavour consists of floral hops, medium bitterness, slight sweet of fruits. 
Nice and simple beer.
Golden colour with medium carbonation. Noble hop aroma which comes through nicely in the taste. Alcohol a bit burning but otherwise well done.

Bottle at tasting, thanks dEnk! Pours a hazy blonde color with a thin creamy white head. Aroma of Belgian hops, citrus and some spices. Flavor is bitter, spicy and with some fruits. Creamy texture, medium carbonation. Nice brew.

330 ml bottle, bought at LCBO Rideau and King Edward (Ottawa), April 11, 2010. White yellow misty, small head. Aroma of Saaz hops mid-dry, notes of lemons. A taste of well blend Saaz hops and sweet barley malt, a little alcohol in the aftertaste. Verry nice strong lager!

330 Ml bottle.  Deep yellow/orange, hazy. Large white head decently maintained. Slightly grassy and citrus in the nose.  Excellent balance of hops and malt. Nice mouthfeel, with bitter finish, but the alcohol comes though a bit too much on the end, and theres a bit of stickiness , taking something away from the palate. Overall a nice, well balanced beer.

Draught at Københavns Ølfestival 2010.
Cloudy yellow coloured with a huge white head.
Fruity aroma of hops and grass.
Fruity flavour of hops and grass.
Dry hoppy finish.

Very thick hazy pour.  Cant see through this once.  Lots of head at first but it faded.  Surprisingly little lacing.  Scent is hard to detect.  Something sweet and slightly boozy noze.  Mouth is very pleasant.  Found myself taking quite a few drinks then having to remember to rate this and pay more attention.  Very drinkable.  Now I like high alcohol boozy beers which is probably why it just went down like water.  A bit of graprefruity tartness that is quickly surpassed by something sweet.  This is replaced by a nice warming boozyness.  I have to say I really like this one.  Probably going to rate this 40% or more higher then the norm due to my like of strong alcoholic tastes.

330 ml bottle. Hazy golden yellow colour, medium-sized creamy white head. Grassy-hoppy, a little peppery malty aroma with a whiff of citrus fruits. The flavour is malty, a little dry, with citrus fruits, hops, alcohol and a warm finish. Medium-bodied, moderately carbonated. A bit too much alcohol in the flavour, otherwise quite good.

Bottle. Pours a hazy gold with sticky white head, heavy lacing all over. Aroma is quite hoppy and boozy, fresh smelling. Taste is pretty awful, alcohol, alcohol, alcohol. I swear rubbing alcohol must have a more enjoyable flavor. Palate is nice and crisp, refreshing. WTF went wrong with the taste of this beer.

330ml swing-top bottle.  Clear bubbly gold with a large white creamy-frothy lasting head - looks sticky! (4-).  Pungent fresh-mown grass & catnip aroma, quite cannabis-like;  underlying graininess.  Taste - is a little weaker than I thought it would be, the hops are crisper, lighter, and dryer, nowhere near as pungent - it lets the sweet freshness of the backing grainy malt shine through - damn, thats eash-drinking ..... you could tell me this is 5% and I would believe you.  Light body, solid yet soft carbonation, just a little dry and astringent from all that nobel hoppity stuff in there - and it finishes quick and hardly all that bitter, just a dry grassy linger, with a hint of extra alcohol.  Im shocked how much I liked this!!
Bottle. Clear yellow with a medium foamy white head. Aroma is malt, corn, sugar, herbal and floral hops. Flavor is malt, herbal hops, floral hops, alcohol. Sticky mouthfeel.

330 ml bottle from LCBO, served cold in a tulip glass. 19AP10.
App.:  Cloudy golden with a nice white foam.
  
Aroma:  Bright citrus/pine/slightly grassy and peppery hops, kinda spicy, some biscuit malt, a touch yeasty with faint esters, kinda fruity as it warms.
  
Palate:  Medium body, moderate carbonation.
  
Flav.:  Lots of citrus hops, somewhat resinous, grassy, decent malt backbone, more yeast than the nose, slightly fruity, more so as it warm; off-dry with good bitterness and a peppery, malty finish.

Nice stuff.

12oz bottle thanks to matt7215 !
Appearance : Hazy yellow small head. Minimal lacing.

Aroma : Chewy malt with crisp hops. A bit citrusy. Some alcohol as well.

Taste : Very malty with some hops and a lot of alcohol. Finish is very warm with some hops. A bit sugary. Rather dry but a bit sweet.

Overall : Nice malty and hoppy profile that I like in the Blond but I dont think this alcohol boost makes it better. Nice beer nonetheless but I keep thinking id rather have the regular blond. This beer is still a nice drink but not as refreshing as the blond. Still pretty clean stuff.

Brown bottle, 330 ml, best before End 10 2011, gift from Luc Bourbonnière or Karl Probst (merci!), savoured on April 15 2010; eye: golden, hazy, no effervescence, nice white head that falls and turns into a tiny sheet, slight lacing; nose: malt, hops, light perfume, alcohol; mouth: malt, hops, light perfume, finale in alcohol with presence of malt, medium body, average carbonation, lightly grainy texture, lightly sweet; overall: ordinary

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 330 ml, meilleure avant Fin 10 2011, cadeau de Luc Bourbonnière ou Karl Probst (merci!), savourée le 15 avril 2010; il : dorée, voilée, pas deffervescence, belle mousse blanche qui tombe et forme un petite couverture, très légère  dentelle; nez : malt, houblon, léger parfum, alcool; bouche : malt, léger houblon, léger parfum, finale en alcool avec présence de malt, corps moyen, carbonatation moyenne, texture légèrement granuleuse, légèrement sucrée; en résumé : ordinaire

This beer is a must try.  Pours a cloudy straw yellow with a thin white head.  Aroma is very hoppy with citrus that is very tangy.  Taste is a little acidic, but a great hop bitterness and citrus flavouring.  A really nice beer, maybe a little more carbonation would be nice.

Bottle. Thanks to Armando, that is Gergely. 
Colour indicates a murky yellow unfiltered beauty with a rocky off-white head. Huge hop aroma along with what seems like Brettanomyces or the likes. Theres lemon and oranges, and its funky. Flavour is sweet malty, sorbet vanilla/citrusy ice-cream with lots of hops, let alone a balanced bitterness, which comes late in the shape of grass and then I feel its growing. Medium-full body with superb vanilla-sorbet features. The flavours come in layers, sweetness, sorbet, tropical fruits. Great beer!

330ml bottle from the LCBO
Pours a very cloudy amber with almost no head or lacing but still lokks appealing
The aroma is bread, cereal, dough, 
the taste is swwet malt floral really nice

Flaske: Lys klar øl med en smule bundfald der gør den sidste tredjedel uklar. Fin skumkrone. Duft af humle citrus, iipa i sit udtryk. Desværre er flasken nok også en smule gammel, så humlen er faded en smule. Smagen er bestemt lige i skabet, og hvis den havde været frisk ville denne øl snildt komme over en 4er men igen er humlen lidt forsvundet, men stadig en god bitterhed. Flot øl.

I thoroughly enjoyed this beer. 
Pours a hazy straw golden colour with a big soapy head that slowly dissolves. The aroma is hops, biscuit, citrus, resin, sugary, good. 
The Flavour pretty much reflects all that as an almost perfect harmonious dance of hops and malts on the tongue, really quite delicious. Finishes on an interesting peppermint note...strange, but good. Will certainly buy again
Its too bad that one out of every three of these seems to be skunked.

Flip-top bottle purchased at LCBO. Poured golden with a huge, soapy head. Aroma of grass, very hoppy and lovely. Very hazy with excellent lacing. Medium bitter taste with some almost sweet notes in the prolonged finish. Overall very enjoyable. Definitely recommended.

Bottle 330 ml  
Appearance : slight haze of dark gold , some amber shade , very light white , bright head. 2+  Nose:  malty , sweet character , sugar empowered , slight hint of hops behind. Flavor/Palate :  fill bodied. Thick malty base with hint of plum followed by bitter heavy hop profile. Some dryness of alcohol.  Fruity hoppy strong lager. Some funk thanks to yeast used. ESL hybrid beer ? Reminds me of Van Pur (smile) , expected more refinery from Christoffel.

330ml Bottle: Pours a beautiful opaque golden yellow, amazing marshmallow white head on top. Aroma is skunky, rye bread dough, lemon and noticeable spicy, herbal hops. She be a hop bomb! Great peppery hop bite off the top, breadiness, quite sharp and very dry. This is top notch for a lager, definitely one of the best Ive had. Excellent.

330ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy light amber, with a off-white head that diminished quickly.  The nose is dried fruit, caramel, and a strong resin smell.  Initial sweetness to the taste, that quickly becomes overpowered by very floral hops.  The hops more or less dominate the taste, which I like.

Bottle, LCBO.  Light yellow, tons of bubbles, fantastic looking ice cream like foamy white head.  Dry, yeasty, dusty hops in pleasing aroma.  Taste is good - almost exactly like the regular Chritoffel Blonde we get here from time to time except with more of a syrupy malt base and more alcohol.  This does not make it better, in fact, it is far less refreshing, but it is still quite flavourful and hoppy, like its younger brother.  Not bad, but Ill stick with the blonde.

.33L bottle - Shared this one w/ SkyCop32.  Picked up at Maruhn Getränke in Darmstadt.Pours a clear amber color. Aromas of hops, hops, and more hops. Maybe a hint of malt. Flavor is all hops, light body with a long dry finish and aftertaste.
Fruity and flowery bouquet. Clear golden with lots of bubbles and thinning white head. Very dry clean hop taste. Very dry aftertaste too.

Bottle at Cafe Gollem, Amsterdam on 18th March 2010. Pours hazy amber with a small white head. Very bitter and hoppy with a strong tingling citric note on the tongue. Strong grapefruit kick and exquisitely bitter hoppy aftertaste.

Bottle from Paul and Karin. Thanks! Pours hazy light amber colour with nice thick white head. Grassy hop nose with some honey notes. Body is thick and creamy, a bit sour and good hoppy finish. Overall a nice brew

Clear golden with a medium white head. Hoppy aroma with hints of malt, grass and piney notes. Flavour was quite dry with plenty of hops, pine, grass and grapefruits. Finished bitter and dry. This is how all european strong lagers should be.

330 ml swing-top bottle from LCBO.  Pours a cloudy yellow-gold with large, billowing white head; good lacing.   Strong herbal/grassy aroma with more subtle citrus and bread.  Taste starts bready but quickly gives way to herbal/grassy hops with a hint of citrus.  Finish is on the dry side.  Really doesnt come across as a high ABV beer.  Very nice.

Bottle. Creamy white excellent fully lasting head. Yellow colour. Modwerate malty and heavy hoppy aroma. Grass and pine notes. Heavy bitter almost harsh flavor. Average heavy bitter finish. Oily palate.

Bottle - 330ml. Hazy blond body with average carbonation and a good, lasting white foamy head. Nice, fresh hoppy aroma with piney and herbal hints. Alcohol is well hidden. its very sharp hoppy taste carries coriander notes and ends with a long bitter/herbal finish. Very good.

Pretty much what I expected.  Strong grassy aroma.  Nice job of covering up not only the alcohol content but the harsh alcohol bitterness associated with poorly brewed high-alcohol content lagers.  Upon sipping plenty of fruitiness, esp. tropical fruit flavours come out along with good maltiness to back it up but after half a bottle the heaviness of the beer shows itself and it starts to become too rich and decadent.  Not really my style but nice to taste.

Bouteille flip-flop de 33 cl. Arômes intenses et complexes de houblon européen (herbacé, floral). Robe blonde et trouble, effervescence moyenne et belle mousse. Bien maltée et ronde en bouche, le houblon est très aromatique (herbacé et floral). On remarque aussi de légères notes fruitées (la levure ?). Finale relativement peu amère (surtout en tenant compte du côté très aromatique du houblon) et légèrement sucrée. Lalcool est aussi plutôt (un peu trop) apparent en finale. Une bière originale !

Hazy golden pour with a big frothy dense head. Bug aroma if hops, lemon and some honey. Flavour is very hoppy with some good pale malts. Medium bodied the alcohol causes the beer to be tad sweet and seems to thicken it a bit. Overall its like a suped up version of their regular christoffel bier.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a big fluffy white head.  Smells of floral hops, malt and candy.  Taste is sweet with some hop bitterness.  Too sweet for my liking.  Mouthfeel is syrupy and smooth.  Overall a nice beer but far too sweet to go back for more.  Last sip of the creamy head was nice.

Bottle [330ml]. Pours a clear, very bubbly golden-orange with a large somewhat-lasting foamy white head (pours darker when I pour the bottom of the bottle into the glass). Aroma of perfumy hops first and foremost followed by some honey, lemon, pale malt and tropical fruit.
Flavour of perfumy hops and alcohol along with pale malt, honey and fruit -- somewhat sweet, but not overly. Average to medium bodied. Alcohol could be better hidden in the flavour and it almost approaches being too sweet, but as it is its still a pretty solid beer.

Pours a pale, cloudy straw.  Aroma is a bit skunky at first, but soon yields to some mild hops.  Strong alcohol taste at first, followed by a mild sweetness, then a lasting bitterness.  High alcohol content gives this a very warming mouthfeel.  Bitterness creates a bit of an anise finish.  Overall interesting, but not particularly my style.

pours lightly hazy golden with a moderate white head. smell is of coffee, lightly roasted malt, a little ripe fruit. taste is strong maltiness, pleasant mature alcohol, pungent herbal hops and bitter, nearly harsh feel aka "manly". distinctly tastes like a "strong euro lager" but a very mature, interesting one.

330ml swing top bottle. Decants a murky unfilterd pale gold lager in the glass with a puffy white 3 finger cap - laces well.

Aromas of biscuit dough over pungent grassy-herbal hopping.
Big pilsner malts in front are tamed by rich, juicy herbaceous hops. Dry finish without a hint of alcohol except for some gentle warming. This is a seductive imperial pilsner with no hint of its strength in the flavor profile.

I understand why the 330ml bottle ...this is so smooth and tasty youd like to session it but beware. This kicks Duvels ass for drinkability.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2014 330 mL bottle.  Pale gold with a huge, rocky, white head.  Strong aroma of grassy Euro hops before you even bring the beer to your nose.  Flavour is not as big, and the malt profile is thin.  Alcohol is partially covered up.  A little on the sweet side.  Interesting one.

Re-rate.  Im an idiot.  This is awesome.

330ml bottle from da LCBO. very nice huge dry blonde beer. im not goin to comment on the style but if you wanna get ripped quick and you enjoy pils malt and nobel hops then this one is for you. light gold with a big white head. far too easy to drink.

Small dinky swing top bottle, pours a beautiful hazy orange with a small but consistant snow white head. Aroma: slight lemon, yeast, caramel & lychee. Flavour: caramel, quite hoppy which I could not
detect in the aroma, alcohol, lemon, banana and yeast with a caramel finish. Not bad.

Fantastic! Smells like its going to be sweet - and hoppy - but happily adds bitter to the sweet and has a really clean finish. But not "clean" in the way that ice beer drinkers like - clean in terms of a good sharp bite. The alcohol is noticeable in the taste, but not overwhelming.

In all, a beautifully balanced beer and one that I will definitely be trying to stock up on.

Bottle: Poured a slightly hazy bright yellow color beer with a large foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of sweet malt with some dry Noble hops notes. Taste is also a somewhat unbalanced mix between some dry hopped Saaz and some overly sweet malt notes with a hint of cereal. Body is quite full with good carbonation and no apparent alcohol. I kinda like the idea of a hoppier Christoffel but just too sweet for my taste buds.

330mL bottle from the Likcbo. Pours a semi-hazy bright gold with a small white cap. Aroma is aggressivelly hoppy, pine needles, minor Pils malt, reminds me of cannabis, but unfortunately skunked. I really like this beer because of its originality. These days its very much in style to brew "an imperial stout", "an IPA" or "a belgian triple". On the other hand you have the traditionalists who stick to a particular style and method that they have done for ages. Christoffel Nobel is a beer which retains traditional style elements but still goes its own way. That alone is worth some appreciation. It has a nice and distinct aroma, good dry hop taste which blends well into the brew and it packs a serious punch too without being dominated by alcohol taste. In general, nothing really dominates this beer except maybe the dry hopping characteristics, and I like my beers well rounded.

Too big for its own good. I can see the attempt. The brewery wanted to make a big good lager with a ton of nobel hops. While I salute the endeavor, something didnt go right. I admit the possibility that something could be wrong with this particular bottle, but I have no reason to think its been poorly handled or anything. At any rate, it tastes like a cheap strong Euro lager or even an American malt liquor (and I dearly apologize to the Christoffel brewers who are probably very nice gentlemen who know a ton about beer and brewing). Theres just a mildly stomach-turning flavor to that sweet malt married to a lager yeast that kills it for me. The boatload of metallic nobel hops dont bring enough spice for me, although there is a relatively nice grassy quality in there. Theres a funny, thick aftertaste that I dont particularly care for, as well. The feel isnt bad, but its hard for me to get past the flavor. As a sidenote, this beer tastes little to nothing like any Czech Pilsener that Ive ever tasted. Anyway, its another beer that Id love to give a second chance particularly if I ever find myself at the brewery.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2009 Bottled 33cl. Courtesy of bierkoning. Appearance: It pours a beautiful hazy golden beer with a nice average sized dense white head. Good lacework. Aroma: The nose is wonderfully hoppy, fruity with mandarin, elderflower, pineapple, mint, Devonshire cream, rose and horse blanket appearing. Flavor and palate: Sublime hop profile. Great balance. Good bitterness. Peppery. A lot of elderflower, mandarin, rose and pineapple showing up again in the taste. Medium to full bodied. Smooth. The alcohol is very nicely hidden. Dry finish with lingering hops and licorice which makes you eager to take another sip. Overall impression: My kind of Imperial IPA or ESL or whatever. Excellent. Clearly underrated in my opinion. Thanks a lot bierkoning!

On tap @ Beiaard. Hazy orange with a small and dense off-white head. Aroma is citrus  fruity and grass. Flavor is mild and soft malty with lots of hops, very refreshing. A great  crossover between lager and IPA. Very ballanced and bitter at the same time.

From tap at Beiaard. Pours hazy orange with a dense, slight off-white head. Creamy. Mild citrus fruity and hoppy aroma. Solid bitter and orange to citrus fruity hops flavoured with a distinct bitterness coming through. Quite dryh finish. Nice one.
Orange colour, white head. Aroma has hops. Flavour is hoppy and fruity. Bitter and dry. Nice one.
Hazy, pale yellow colour with thick head. Aroma is very zesty and acidic. Flavour is lemony and fresh. Sharpness with a light bitter hop finish.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2009 Bottled from Bierkoning, Amsterdam. Hazy yellow/orange coloured, white head. Overwhelming hoppy nose, Saaz all the way, great. Very bitter flavour right from the beginning, which even increases towards the finish. Interesting style, something like a "European" Double IPA. I personally like those hoppy beers more easy to drink, so ill stick with the Christoffel Blond, but its certainly a nice try.
At Wildeman. Murky yellow body with slight head. Hoppy nose. Nice dry hoppy taste, some citrus, other fruits. Nice bitter finish.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2009 Update: Crazy beer, Has acetone-ish elements because of the high hopping of this type; have seem similar profile in some bottles of Gaspar. Original: THIS IS NOT AN IPA. This is clearly a lager, as indicated by the label stating "bottom fermented." Thus, at this ABV, I suggest a European Strong Lager, as some other rater has also suggested.

Insanely dry, grassy, bitter - a seriously tingling bitterness pervades this whole thing. The beer is thinner than most Euro Strong Lagers or even American Imperial Pilsners; none of that cloying sweetness. This is Saaz/Tettnang to the extreme; flowery and intense. Some barnyardyness. The flavor is almost too intense and shows a hint of acetone. Beautiful head, beautiful golden, orangey color.

The second I read about this beer I knew I would want it. Christoffel makes very natural beers, and this is all hops. Delightful. Thanks to bierkoning!

text: Swingtop bottle 0,33ltr: Hazy yellow brew from this brewery familiar of its hoppy and bitter beers, and this new one is no exception.

Swing top bottle (BB 12/2010). 
Thanks bierkoning.
Hazy yellow color, small white head, lace. Cat piss, barnyard nose. Cat piss, grassy fresh hay, sweet lemony flavor. Lively carbonation. Long lingering bitterness. This is an extreme cat piss -hop experience.  Similar to Plevna Severin.

Bottled. Hazy pale orange colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is barnyard, some spices and mild fruityness lurking in the background. Flavour is fruity, grassy and very refreshing. Some slight herbal notes as well as some yeastyness.
Orange colored brew. Hoppy aroma, european style. Yeasty, malty, dry hoppy flavor. Thick mouthfee, some apple. Nice brew.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours a clear yellow with a small white head and a spicy aroma with some malts in there too. The taste is very hoppy, both floral and spicey, I detect cinnamon, coriander, something peppery, lemon and apple and some malty sweetness. A long and very nice bitter finish. A lovely new brew

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2009 A little hazy, yellow/golden colored beer, with a thick foamy white head. The aroma of hops, with fruits like citrus/lemon. A little spicey. The taste of bitter hops, a little liquorice and mint. There are some spices like koriander. Fruity like citrus. It is a little dry and bitter. The aftertaste is long and in a lovely way bitter. A very good newcomer of the Christoffel brewery.

Bottled. Aroma has hops and fruitiness. Hazy, blonde coloured beer with a white head. Taste is a bit malty, fruity, some grass, citrus. Medium bodied. Didn’t really taste like a strong IPA. However, well brewed, well balanced and has quality ingredients. Well worth a try!

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2010 Bottle from De Bierkoning. Very cloudy, almost milky yellow colour, creamy white head. Aroma of sweet citrusfruits, mostly lemons, hops, a hint of alcohol. Flavour is soft and sweet, lemon, a hint of mint and some alcohol. Soft grassy/earthy bitter finish. Really good and fullbodied, soft carbonation and rounded mouthfeel. Its actually an unfiltered strong lager, but with all the qualities of a good strong IPA. Very well done! 849418
Re-rate: Ive had this a couple of times now, and am not as enthousiastic as I was before, especially not when its from tap. The combination of the alcohol with the hops is quite harsh at times, and its rather sweet imo. Still a really good beer, but not a 4.3. 748416
At an mitra in purmerend, 330ml beugelbottle, golden/orange, smal head, full fruits with spicy hinds, lots of nice flavor,  very nice one.
330 ml bottle. yellow colour. small white fading head. hoppy taste. alcohol not to present.

Swing top bottle. Blonde, hazy. Vanilla, chalk, mint and flowery hops in the aroma. Firm fruit( mandarin, lemon) and flowery hops in the flavor. Some malt character. Very well balanced. Long hopbitter aftertaste with mint. Excellent!
